awd_titl_txt: Regulation of Temporal and Spatial Organization of Newborn GnRH Neurons by IGF Signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
How newborn neurons are organized into the right locations with the right timing to form functional circuits is a fundamental question in developmental neurobiology. An attractive model system in which to address this question is the Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neuronal system. GnRH neurons are master regulators of the reproductive system. They secrete GnRH peptides to initiate reproductive activity. Abnormal development of GnRH neurons can lead to reproductive disorders. Although significant advances have been made in understanding the central importance of GnRH neurons in reproduction, very little is known about where the GnRH progenitor (i.e., undifferentiated) cells are located in the developing nervous system and how they are instructed to become GnRH neurons. This project fills this gap in our knowledge. The anticipated results will provide new knowledge on how insulin-like growth factor (IGF) signaling, a major embryonic growth-promoting pathway, regulates GnRH neuronal development. The knowledge gained from this project may have applications in the aquaculture industry and will help understand the etiology of reproductive disorders. This project provides training opportunities for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. The students participate in all aspects of this cutting-edge research project. In collaboration with the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History, the project also includes the development of a summer camp curriculum in neurobiology, entitled "Shining Neurons in the Brain!", for K-12 students. This and other outreach activities make this NSF-funded research accessible to the public. 

An attractive model system in which to address the question of how newborn neurons are organized into the right locations with the right timing to form functional circuits is the GnRH neuronal system. GnRH neurons emerge from the nasal/olfactory placode in early embryos and undertake a long-distance migration from the olfactory region to the preoptic area and hypothalamus. The embryonic origin(s) of GnRH progenitor cells is still under debate. Little is known about how these progenitor cells are specified to give rise to GnRH neurons. Most vertebrate species have a second GnRH gene that is expressed in the midbrain. Much less is known about the GnRH2 neuron development and regulation. This project tests the hypothesis that the two types of GnRH neurons originate from the cranial neural crest- and/or optical placode-derived progenitor cells and that IGF signaling regulates the emergence of GnRH neurons at the right time and location by controlling the proliferation, migration, and/or survival of their progenitor cells. Perturbation of IGF signaling in a critical time window during early embryogenesis alters the temporal and spatial organization of the newborn GnRH neurons, which, in turn, affects reproductive function later in life. Aim 1 investigates the embryonic origins of GnRH neurons; Aim 2 determines whether IGF signaling regulates the emergence of the GnRH neurons by controlling  migration, proliferation, and/or survival of their progenitor cells, and Aim 3 determines the long-term reproductive consequences of this regulation.

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
In vertebrates including humans, reproduction is under the regulation of hypothalamus-pituitary-gonadal axis. At the top of this 3 tier endocrine system are gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons. These neurons secrete the hormone GnRH to initiate the reproduction process. Although major advances have been made in understanding the functional importance of the GnRH neurons in reproduction, where these neurons come from and how they are specified during early development is still under debate. In addition to the well-studied GnRH1 gene, most vertebrate species including humans have one or two additional GnRH genes. Compared to the GnRH1 neurons, much less is known about the development and regulation of GnRH2 and GnRH3 neurons. A major limitation in the field is that the most widely used animal model, the mouse,  is unusual among the vertebrates in that it only has a single GnRH gene. Many other vertebrates including humans and zebrafish have 2 GnRH genes. The objective of this is to take advance of the free-living and transparent zebrafish embryos to determine the embryonic origin of GnRH neurons. Another goal is to characterize the insulin-like growth factor (IGF) signaling system, a central growth promoting hormone pathway, and to determine its role in regulating GnRH neuron development and in regulating cell migration, proliferation, and/or differentiation. In spite of the many challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, we have mapped the embryonic origins of GnRH neurons in zebrafish embryos. We have characterized the zebrafish IGF signaling system, including IGF ligands, receptors, binding proteins and intracellular signaling pathways. Our results suggest that IGF signaling is critical for the timing of both GnRH2 and GnRH3 neuron emergence as well as for the spatial distribution of GnRH3 neurons. Several intracellular signaling proteins, including PI3 kinase., Akt and Sgk1, act downstream of the IGF receptor. Furthermore, cell-type specific expression of IGF binding proteins is critical. These locally expressed IGF binding proteins bind to and sequester IGF in the IGF-IGF binding protein complexes. Papp-aa, a zinc metalloproteinase, degrades IGF binding proteins and frees IGFs. We have further revealed a novel role of Stc1a, a hypocalcemic hormone, in regulating IGF signaling. Results from this NSF-sponsored project have been disseminated broadly by meeting presentations, publications in refereed journals, web sites, undergraduate classes, and various outreach activities. To date, 15 papers have been published and 2 are under review. This project has provided training opportunities for many undergraduates, graduates, postdoctoral fellows, and K12 students. The involvement of undergraduates is especially important considering this critical stage of their development. Many of our ungraduated researchers have made important contributions and served as co-authors. Of note, Ms. Allison Goldstein, graduated with Higher Honor. Her thesis work contributed to two publications, and she serves as a co-author in both. She is now a graduate student at Harvard University. Ms. Helena Li graduated with Higher Honor and received the “UPiN Director’s award for Outstanding Achievements in Research, in the Classroom and in Teaching or Service”. Mr. Luke Rollings co-authored a paper and accepted into the PhD program at the University of Michigan.  As an outreach activity, several summer camp sessions for K12 school students were organized in collaboration with the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History. During the Covid-19 pandemic, we worked with the Developing Future Biologists, a University of Michigan trainee-run outreach initiative, and provided zebrafish embryos for DFB trainees. We strongly believe that this NSF-sponsored project has had a positive impact on this country's scientific mission by generating new knowledge and helping to train the next generation of research scientists and by community engagement.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2022
Modified by: Cunming Duan
